Center for Combustion Energy School of Vehicle and Mobility Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China Graphical abstract The integration of data science into electrocatalysis has revolutionized the discovery of high-performance catalysts for sustainable energy applications. To emphasize the role of data science and guide future research in electrocatalyst design, this mini-review traces the evolution from low-dimensional data science—rooted in density functional theory (DFT) descriptors such as d-band center and binding/adsorption energies—to high-dimensional analytics powered by large-scale computational datasets and machine learning (ML). First, DFT-derived parameters establish predictive volcano models for various electrochemical reactions, linking atomic-scale descriptors to macroscopic performance within the framework of low-dimensional data science. Meanwhile, with the development of large-scale datasets, ML deciphers complex structure–property relationships, accelerating the design of promising electrocatalysts. Additionally, machine learning potentials (MLPs) bridge quantum precision and scalability, not only accelerating thermodynamic adsorption energy calculations but also enabling simulations of dynamic catalytic mechanisms more efficiently. Finally, we discuss emerging opportunities to deepen data science’s impact. This mini-review highlights the transformative role of data science in bridging theoretical insights, computational efficiency, and experimental validation, ultimately accelerating the design of next-generation electrocatalysts for a sustainable energy future. Keywords Electrocatalyst Data science Density functional theory Large-scale computational database Machine learning Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The development of clean energy conversion and storage technologies, such as fuel cells, electrolyzers, and batteries, is crucial for a sustainable future [1]. At the heart of these technologies are electrochemical reactions, including the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [2], oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [3], hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [4], carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) [5], and electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis such as nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) [6]. High-performance electrocatalysts are indispensable for accelerating these reactions, enabling the efficient transformation of abundant molecules (e.g., water, CO2, and N2) into value-added products such as hydrogen, synthetic fuels, and ammonia [7]. However, exploring electrocatalysts with optimal activity and stability remains challenging due to the vast combinatorial space of material compositions, structures, and synthesis conditions. To address these challenges, the electrocatalysis community has pursued diverse strategies for catalyst design, including doping [8], alloying [9], and surface modification [10], aiming to optimize electronic structures, enhance active site availability, and promote favorable adsorption energies [11]. Over time, the development of these strategies has reflected a broader evolution in electrocatalyst research, which is generally categorized into Four Paradigms [12]: empirical science (Fig. 1 a), theoretical science (Fig. 1 b), computational science (Fig. 1 c), and data-driven science (Fig. 1 d). While data-driven science—often termed the “fourth paradigm”—has revolutionized methodologies through its prominence in big data analytics, it is important to recognize that all paradigms fundamentally operate as forms of data science, distinguished by the scale and dimensionality of their datasets. Before the 20th century, researchers used trial-and-error experimentation to design electrocatalysts for various electrochemical reactions with optimized current density, overpotential, or Faradaic efficiency metrics (Fig. 1 a). These efforts generated isolated experimental data points, which gradually accumulated into empirical rules and theoretical models, such as the Butler-Volmer equation for describing current–potential relationships [13,14], Tafel’s equation for evaluating reaction kinetics [15], and Sabatier’s principle for optimizing adsorbates’ adsorption strengths [16]). Specifically, the Sabatier principle states that an ideal catalyst should bind reactants, products, and intermediates—neither too weakly nor too strongly—to achieve optimal performance, providing a fundamental guideline for electrocatalyst design (Fig. 1 b). Direct binding energy of some adsorbates can be measured by ultra-high vacuum techniques such as temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) [17], but the simulations were unavailable at the time [18]. Consequently, model-driven approaches still required iterative trial-and-error experimentation, making the process labor-intensive and time-consuming. The evolution of quantum chemical theory in the 20th century established the foundation for computational science like density functional theory (DFT), revolutionizing the rational design of electrocatalysts by enabling direct evaluation of intermediate states binding energies and electronic structures (Fig. 1 c) [19]. DFT provides essential theoretical descriptors, such as the d-band center [20] and Gibbs free energy of intermediate adsorption [19], which can bridge atomic-scale insights with macroscopic experimental catalytic performance, enabling a deeper understanding of the catalytic mechanism. Moreover, DFT facilitates the generation of data, leveraging theoretical models to guide catalyst design more efficiently. Entering the 21st century, the exponential growth of experimental data and computational power has positioned data-driven science at the forefront of catalysis research, driving the emergence of big data analytics and data-driven methodologies (Fig. 1 d). Pioneering electrocatalyst datasets, such as the Digital Catalysis Platform (DigCat) [21] and Catalysis Hub [22], have integrated multi-scale catalytic properties spanning macro-level metrics (e.g., experimental current density, overpotentials) and micro-level features (e.g., crystal structures, surface energetics, and reaction networks), thereby enabling high-throughput screening and data-driven discovery of advanced electrocatalysts. While big data offers valuable guidance for identifying promising catalysts (especially electrocatalysts), modern data science in electrocatalysis involves high-dimensional datasets that encapsulate complex relationships between material compositions, structures, and catalytic performance metrics, thereby complicating the extraction of chemically meaningful and actionable insights for targeted catalyst design. To address this challenge, artificial intelligence (AI) has emerged as a versatile and robust tool. Specifically, machine learning (ML) (Fig. 1 d) [23] can construct mathematical models that decode intricate patterns and uncover hidden relationships within vast datasets. In electrocatalysis, ML has already driven remarkable advancements in rationalizing catalysts, such as single atom catalysts [24], metal oxide catalysts [25], and high-entropy alloy catalysts [26], for critical reactions like ORR, OER, HER, and CO2RR. Beyond data-driven catalyst screening, ML also plays a pivotal role at the atomistic level through machine learning potentials (MLPs). MLPs are surrogate models trained on quantum mechanical data, enabling precise and efficient dynamic simulations of reaction pathways and adsorption energetics [27]. By achieving near-DFT-level accuracy with orders-of-magnitude speedup over large-scale structure models, MLPs bridge the gap between quantum mechanical precision and large-scale exploration of catalytic materials, thereby overcoming the computational limitations of conventional DFT-based methods [28]. To emphasize the role of data science and guide future research in electrocatalyst design, this mini-review is based on the third and fourth research paradigms, beginning with an examination of low-dimensional data science rooted in DFT-computed and experimental data, followed by an exploration of high-dimensional datasets and their role in holistic catalyst design. Within this big data paradigm, ML technologies will be highlighted for their ability to decode complex patterns, predict catalytic performance, and accelerate dynamic simulations. Integrating low-dimensional physical insights and high-dimensional data analytics is a promising strategy for accelerating next-generation electrocatalyst discovery for sustainable energy applications. 2 Low-dimensional DFT-driven data science for decoding catalytic mechanisms and design principles DFT calculations have been widely employed in electrocatalysis research for decades, leading to significant advancements, including (i) the development of theoretical descriptors that correlate physical insights with catalytic activities [29–31] and (ii) the widespread adoption of catalytic volcano models to rationalize activity–selectivity relationships through scaling principles [32,33]. Recently, the analysis of electrochemical surface states (i.e., the electrochemistry-induced surface coverage and reconstruction) [34,35] has gained recognition for probing surface evolution during electrochemical reactions; these advanced approaches still fundamentally depend on DFT-derived adsorption energies—the core parameters in traditional descriptor-based frameworks. Given the foundational role of descriptors and volcano models in electrocatalysis, our data science-driven exploration mainly focuses on these essential methodologies. Experimental studies in electrocatalysis often yield sparse datasets that, while capturing macroscopic trends, struggle to unravel atomic-scale physical insights due to the complex interplay of electronic structure, surface geometry, and reaction environment. The DFT method bridges this gap by providing essential theoretical descriptors across three key categories: electronic descriptors, including d-band center [20], eg orbital filling [36] and p-band center [37]; thermodynamic descriptors, including adsorption energy of key intermediate [38]; and geometric descriptors, including coordination number [39], bond lengths [40], and surface strain [29]. By integrating these theoretical parameters with experimental metrics (e.g., H2O2 selectivity, current density, and overpotential) within a unified two-dimensional framework, researchers can systematically link physicochemical descriptors to macroscopic catalytic performance. Fig. 2 a illustrates the relationship between H2O2 selectivity and the Nb d-band center in MNb2O6 columbites (M = Cu, Ni, Co, Fe, and Mn) [30]. Among them, NiNb2O6, with an optimally tuned d-band center, achieves the highest H2O2 selectivity. This indicates that an ideal catalyst surface should possess a d-band center that balances adsorption strength, promoting H2O2 formation while inhibiting over-adsorption or excessive dissociation of intermediates. Fig. 2 b illustrates that the binding energy difference between O2* and HOOH* intermediates (ΔE = EO2* – EHOOH*) at single metal sites effectively describes the variation in the H2O2 selectivity of covalent organic framework single-atom catalysts (COF-366-M) [31]. The trend indicates that as ΔE approaches zero, COF-366-M catalysts exhibit enhanced H2O2 selectivity. Fig. 2 c establishes a volcano relationship between HER activity and surface strain in strained Pt-skin core–shell catalysts (IMC@Pt), with peak specific activity emerging at 4 % compressive strain under acidic conditions [29]. These typical case studies demonstrate how computational descriptors and experimental metrics can be unified through volcano plots, where the apex may represent the optimal activity. Recent advances in theoretical understanding and computational power have paved the way for the development of fully theoretical volcano models to predict electrocatalytic activity for reactions such as ORR [33,41], OER [42,43], HER [44,45], and CO2RR [32,46]. These models are rooted in DFT-calculated data points, scaling relationships [47], and microkinetic modeling [33,48], following a systematic data-science approach: (i) calculating adsorption energies or activation barriers for key intermediates (e.g., O*, OH*, and H*) to generate theoretical dataset; (ii) identifying scaling relationships between the adsorption energies of different intermediates within the dataset, simplifying the prediction of catalytic activity by condensing it to a single descriptor for reactions involving multiple intermediates; and (iii) deriving/constructing volcano models by integrating these relationships with microkinetic models. These plots illustrate the relationship between catalytic activity and the binding energies of key reaction intermediates. For instance, Fig. 2 d–f demonstrate the calculation of adsorption energies for intermediates such as O*, OH*, OOH*, and O2* on atomically dispersed metal nitrogen-carbon (M−N−C) catalysts [33], forming datasets that reveal universal scaling relationships between adsorption energies of HO* and other intermediates, i.e., O* (Fig. 2 d), HOO* (Fig. 2 e), and O2* (Fig. 2 f). These relationships enable a predictive volcano model for ORR activity by defining the Gibbs free energy of OH (GOH*) as a key descriptor. Further refinements incorporate environmental variables, such as electric field effects, yielding pH-dependent volcano models for ORR under a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale [33], as shown in Fig. 2 g. Similarly, a pH-dependent CO2RR volcano model [32] for single-atom and polyatomic Sn catalysts (Fig. 2 h) was constructed using Gibbs free energy of OCHO* (GOCHO*) as the primary descriptor, based on the scaling relationship between GOCHO* and GCO* and the electric field effects and solvation effects such as potential of zero charges. Additionally, theoretical volcano plots have also been developed for OER [42,43] and HER [44,45], utilizing the Gibbs free energy difference between O* and OH* (GO* − GOH*) as a descriptor for predicting OER overpotentials, and G H* for HER current densities. These advancements highlight how theoretical methodologies and data science enhance the predictive capabilities of computational models, driving progress in electrocatalysis. With the growing demand for a comprehensive exploration of catalytic materials, evaluating electrocatalytic properties and capturing evolving trends across a broader range of candidate electrocatalysts has become increasingly important. High-dimensional computational and experimental datasets enable the identification of such trends across chemical space. In the following section, we discuss how high-dimensional data science leverages these datasets to accelerate electrocatalyst discovery. 3 High-dimensional data science in electrocatalysis The increasing availability of computational power has enabled the high-throughput calculation of a large number of materials. Representative studies have leveraged these capabilities to guide the design of electrocatalysts, such as transition metal single-atom catalysts for NRR [49] and Fe-doped MoS2 nanosheets for pH-universal overall OER and HER [50]. Notably, these efforts have contributed to the growth of large-scale computational datasets and the development of open-access repositories, thereby expanding opportunities for materials discovery. Among these, the Materials Project [51] database is a cornerstone, aggregating structural and property data for over 154,000 materials in its latest release (v2022.10.28). For electrocatalyst research, this platform has systematically calculated bulk Pourbaix diagrams [52–54] for these large-scaled materials, mapping their thermodynamic stability across diverse electrochemical conditions—such as potential and pH ranges—to reveal corrosion mechanisms and phase transitions in aqueous environments. To identify stable electrocatalysts, the maximum Gibbs free energy difference (ΔG pbx_max) should be below 0.5 eV/atom [53], and the solid phase should be included at defined potentials and pH values [55]. Data mining of bulk Pourbaix diagram datasets has accelerated the discovery of stable metal oxide electrocatalysts [56] for ORR, OER, CER, and HER reactions across acidic, neutral, and alkaline conditions, providing valuable guidance for experimental design (Fig. 3 a). Notably, Sb2WO6 [57] has been experimentally validated as stable under both acidic and alkaline ORR conditions, bridging theoretical predictions with experimental validation. Beyond bulk aqueous stability, surface properties are critical for electrocatalytic performance, and several large-scale computational datasets have been found for uncovering surface structure–property relationships (Fig. 3 b). Catalysis-Hub (Catalysis-Hub.org) [22] has stored a high-throughput computational surface reactions database for bimetals, pure metals, metal oxides, and oxyhydroxide from 119 publications, with more than 130,000 adsorption and reaction energies cataloged to date. While this dataset provides valuable insights into surface reactivity, its scope remains limited regarding material diversity and adsorption configurations, leaving gaps in exploring more complex catalytic systems. The Open Catalyst Project (opencatalystproject.org) has significantly expanded the scope of available data. Its OC20 dataset [58], part of the Materials Project ecosystem, catalogs ∼ 872,000 adsorption energies for key adsorbates (e.g., small adsorbates, C1/C2 compounds, and N/O-containing intermediates) on the surface structures of 11,409 bulk materials, including metals and intermetallic compounds. The OC22 dataset [59] further extends materials to 4728 unary and binary metal oxides (A x O y and A x B y O z ), adding 43,189 adsorption configurations that provide critical insights into oxide-specific catalytic behavior. Further expanding electrocatalysts dataset diversity, the Open DAC 2023 (ODAC23) dataset (open-dac.github.io) [60] has provided a comprehensive DFT-based CO2 and H2O adsorption dataset for ∼8000 metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), totaling ∼1,76,000 adsorption energy calculations. These databases provide valuable surface data for electrocatalysts and can significantly enhance the understanding of catalyst behavior, improve the design of next-generation materials, and guide experimental efforts through high-throughput screening and data mining techniques. Recently, the Digital Catalysis Platform (DigCat, www.digcat.org) [21] has further expanded computational and experimental data availability (Fig. 3 c). As of 23 Feb 2025, it offers access to over 4,00,000 experimental and 429,473 computational datasets, covering eight electrocatalysts systems, such as metal-X (e.g., carbides, nitrites, and oxides), metal and alloy catalysts, carbon-based catalysts, and M−C−N catalysts, for a range of electrochemical reactions. By systematically analyzing the reported experimental data stored in DigCat, researchers can uncover catalytic trends, enabling further exploration of meaningful research directions in electrocatalysis (Fig. 3 d). For instance, an analysis of ORR activity across more than 100 reported M−N−C catalysts (upper Figure in Fig. 3 d) revealed significant pH-dependent behavior, which could not be well-explained by previous theoretical frameworks and models, highlighting the need for a deeper understanding of how pH influences catalytic performance on the RHE scale. This finding has spurred the development of comprehensive pH-dependent ORR volcano models on the RHE scale (Fig. 2 g), which can be used to predict ORR activity at various pH conditions [33]. In addition to its extensive experimental datasets, DigCat provides valuable computational insights. For example, the adsorption energies of key intermediates, HO* and O*, on stable single-atom metal-N4 (M−N4) structures, where M represents metals, can be analyzed within the dataset (lower Figure in Fig. 3 d) [61]. By using these adsorption energies as descriptors to predict 1O2 generation efficiency, a high-performance Fe single-atom catalyst (Fe-SAC) was synthesized and tested, showing promising decontamination performance and stability. These large-scale computational and experimental datasets have revolutionized big data science in electrocatalysis. While we can identify trends within the dataset, its massive scale and high dimensionality make it challenging to uncover meaningful relationships between compositions and properties. It is critical to find tools to efficiently analyze and extract insights from these complex datasets, enabling us to bridge the gap between raw data and actionable knowledge. 4 ML-enabled screening of promising electrocatalysts ML methods have emerged as transformative tools for extracting meaningful patterns from large datasets, efficiently identifying structure–property–performance relationships to uncover the origins of catalytic activity and enabling accurate predictions for unknown systems with minimal computational cost. The ML workflow typically involves data generation, feature representation, model construction, model interpretability, and model validation, each critical for advancing applications in electrocatalysis. Data generation currently relies on experimental results (e.g., from published literature and laboratory experiments) or DFT calculations. High-throughput computational databases tailored for surface science (Fig. 3 b) have been built, providing scalable datasets for training ML models (which will be discussed later in this paper). Feature representation focuses on selecting descriptors that encode material properties, such as elemental attributes (e.g., atomic radius, electronegativity, and atomic weight) [62] and crystal structural parameters, including crystal geometry and surface adsorption configurations [63], which are crucial for linking atomic-scale details to macroscopic performance. For experimental data, compositions are typically used to generate features based on the elemental properties contained within the compositions. Researchers can either define custom statistical calculations of elemental properties or use tools like the Matminer [64] Python library to automate the extraction of elemental descriptors. This elemental representation can be generally applied to describe various electrocatalysts, such as multicomponent oxides [25], transition metal phosphides [65], etc. For computational data, since structures are accessible and serve as the basis for properties, crystal graphs [63,66] are often utilized to be defined as features. While the crystal graphs can also be extended to surface science, more specialized features that describe local coordination environments near adsorption sites can enhance accuracy in modeling surface reactivity. Fig. 4 a illustrates an example of feature extraction around an adsorption site. One method involves creating a fingerprint vector [67] by tabulating the types of coordinated elements near the adsorption site, using descriptors such as atomic number (Z), Pauling electronegativity (χ), coordination number (CN), and median adsorption energy (ΔE) for intermetallic compounds. Another method involves using elemental labels for the atoms surrounding a symmetric adsorption site (e.g., on-top, 3-fold fcc-hollow, or hcp-hollow sites on the (111) surface) [68] or linking nodes in a connected graph [69] to describe high-entropy electrocatalysts. Model construction plays a crucial role in guiding the design of electrocatalysts, following data generation and feature construction. ML models can be broadly classified into three categories: supervised learning [70] (using well-labeled datasets), unsupervised learning [71] (using unlabeled datasets), and semi-supervised learning [72] (using partially labeled datasets). Currently, the application of ML in electrocatalysis predominantly relies on supervised methods that leverage well-labeled datasets. Commonly employed supervised ML algorithms include support vector machine (SVM), tree-based ensemble models such as random forest (RF), gradient-boosted decision trees (GBDT), and eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) for tabular data [73]. Deep learning architectures like convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and graph neural networks (GNNs) are widely used to capture graph-structured representations of materials [74]. These models are typically trained to predict key catalytic metrics, including experimental observables (e.g., current density [25]) and computational properties (e.g., adsorption energies [69]). Fig. 4b provides an example of using supervised learning methods, specifically XGBoost, to predict the current density for the ORR at 0.8 V referenced to the RHE and compares the experimental and predicted values on both the training and test sets [25]. Unsupervised clustering includes representative algorithms, such as K-means [75], Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN) [76], and AGglomerative NESting (AGNES) [77]. For association analysis, algorithms such as Apriori [78] are commonly applied. Dimensionality reduction techniques include methods like Principal Component Analysis (PCA) [79] and t-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (t-SNE) [80], etc. Currently, dimensionality reduction techniques are mainly used in electrocatalysis to map high-dimensional data into lower dimensions while preserving essential information, aiding visualization and pattern recognition. Fig. 4 c presents a t-SNE representation of ∼4000 DFT-calculated adsorption sites for Cu-containing alloys, highlighting Cu-Al alloys with the most diverse adsorption sites (left in Fig. 4 c). Cu-Al bridge sites with near-optimal ΔECO values form cluster 3 (right in Fig. 4 c), while other clusters represent sites that bind CO either too strongly (clusters 1 and 2) or too weakly (clusters 4 and 5). These findings suggest that Cu-Al catalysts could be highly active and selective for CO2 electroreduction to C2H4 and have been validated using experiments [67]. Semi-supervised learning is an ML approach between supervised and unsupervised learning. It utilizes a partially labeled dataset, typically a small amount of labeled data combined with a large amount of unlabeled data. Common Semi-supervised learning models include self-training [81], semi-supervised support vector machines [82], and generative models [83]. Although semi-supervised learning [72] has been applied in materials science design, there is limited research on its application in electrocatalysis. Similarly, unsupervised learning techniques currently only were restricted to dimensionality reduction. To advance ML-driven electrocatalyst discovery, further exploration of these methods in designing electrocatalysts is warranted. For instance, unsupervised clustering could reveal electrocatalysts families with similar surface properties, adsorption site configurations, or reaction environments—guiding experimental prioritization. Likewise, semi-supervised learning methods could enable the prediction of adsorption energies or catalytic activity using only a small number of labeled examples alongside a large body of unlabeled structural or compositional data. As these approaches reduce dependence on fully labeled datasets, they offer promising pathways for more efficient and scalable catalyst screening. Model interpretability analysis has gained increasing attention since ML methods have often been considered “black boxes”, making it difficult to understand the underlying physical mechanisms. To address this, researchers have applied techniques such as feature importance analysis [85], Shapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) [20], and partial dependence plots [86] to uncover patterns linking input variables to model predictions of materials performance. These techniques have also been applied in the analysis of electrocatalysis. For instance, after building an ML model using XGBoost to distinguish eligible and non-eligible catalysts in analyzing transition metal-based catalysts (TM@VB/C-Nn-BC3) for NRR [87], SHAP revealed that a reduced valence electron of metal (Nv) and a moderate nitrogen substitution (Nn) can balance charge distribution at active sites, which has been verified by DFT-based electronic structure evaluations. In addition, inherently explainable architectures have also been designed, like the atomic graph attention network (AGAT) [84], which employs attention scores (αij) to prioritize influential atomic interactions during prediction. Visualization of AGAT’s outputs, such as adsorption-induced energy and force distributions (Fig. 4 e), confirmed that perturbations localize within the third nearest atomic neighbors—a behavior consistent with domain knowledge. Ultimately, a key goal of ML in electrocatalysis is to design promising catalysts, which require model validation using experimental and computational methods. Fig. 4 f–g illustrates the experimental validation process, showing model-guided synthesis, characterization, and electrochemical performance tests. For high-entropy alloys, experimental validation of ML-recommended compositions using the method in Fig. 4 d demonstrated comparable ORR performance compared to conventional Pt/C catalysts. 5 MLPs-enabled catalytic thermodynamic and dynamic analysis The adsorption energies of key reactants are essential descriptors for evaluating the activity of heterogeneous catalysts, as shown in Fig. 2. While high-throughput computational surface science has made significant progress in generating adsorption energy datasets for species such as *H, *O, and *CO (Fig. 3 b), these datasets remain small compared to large-scale repositories like the Materials Project [51], which hosts over 100,000 bulk materials. Expanding these datasets to encompass a broader range of reactions involving diverse surfaces, adsorbates, and active sites would require extensive computational resources, potentially amounting to billions of CPU days due to the vast combinatorial space. ML models offer a promising alternative for predicting adsorption energies, but their accuracy and generalizability are heavily dependent on the quality and diversity of the training datasets, which are typically derived from DFT computations. For larger systems or more complex reactants, these DFT calculations can become inefficient and time-consuming, limiting the effectiveness of ML models. Beyond thermodynamic properties, catalytic systems exhibit dynamic complexity under operational conditions, including surface diffusion and adsorbate-induced reconstruction [88]. While ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) methods provide a rigorous framework for simulating catalyst dynamics through explicit electronic structure calculations [89], its prohibitive computational cost restricts applications to realistic catalytic systems and environments. MLPs have emerged as a transformative solution, enabling accelerated adsorption energy calculations and large-scale simulations of dynamic catalyst evolution [62]. MLPs are constructed using data generated from DFT calculations, where total energies and atomic forces serve as training targets. By learning the relationship between local atomic environments and these properties, MLPs can accurately reproduce potential energy surfaces (PES) [90]. Various MLPs have been developed, including neural network potentials [91] (NNPs), graph neural networks (GNNs) (e.g., SchNet [92] and DimeNet++ [93]), and kernel-based methods such as the Gaussian Approximation Potentials (GAP) [94,95]. These models have been widely used to accelerate adsorption energy calculations and unravel dynamic catalytic mechanisms, with some recent applications in electrocatalysts. Applications in accelerating adsorption energy calculations: The AdsorbML framework [96] exemplifies MLP implementation, employing GNNs to streamline adsorption energy calculations. This method balances precision and computational cost and achieves an 87.36 % success rate in locating the optimal configuration with ∼2000 × accelerated processing. To improve sampling efficiency, active learning workflows combine GAP with Metropolis-Hastings (MH) simulations (Fig. 5 a), gradually constructing training sets with minimal DFT calculations while exploring configuration spaces more thoroughly [97]. As shown in Fig. 5 b, this strategy identifies global minima with formation energies comparable to or lower than previous benchmarks in most cases. Unraveling catalytic mechanisms: MD simulations accelerated by equivariant GNNs at the Au(100)-water interface revealed that the ORR proceeds via an associative pathway, where *OOH intermediates directly reduce to dual *OH species with the assistance of neighboring water molecules, rather than dissociating into *OH and *O (Fig. 5 c) [91]. Additionally, a high-dimensional neural network (HDNN) potential is used to simulate hydrogen evolution at the HCl(aq)/Pt(111) interface. The results reveal the presence of adsorbed Had/H2Oad on the surface and demonstrate that the preferred reaction mechanism varies with surface coverage, emphasizing the dual mechanistic nature of HER on Pt(111) [98]. MLP-enhanced free energy calculations further uncovered a surface pre-melting mechanism governing nanocatalyst activity, modifiable through engineered point defects (Fig. 5 d) [99]. Furthermore, similar to Fig. 5 a, data-efficient MLP was proposed using active learning strategies that combine enhanced sampling with sequential model refinement. By integrating Gaussian processes for transition path discovery and GNNs for uniform PES accuracy, these workflows enable the efficient construction of reactive potentials. This workflow successfully simulated ammonia decomposition on FeCo alloys, revealing nearly identical free energy profiles to pure Fe systems and challenging the presumed mechanistic role of Co dopants [100]. However, challenges related to MLP applications still remain, including but not limited to: 1) how to ensure a high-accuracy when predicting the energies of magnetic systems, 2) how to ensure a fair sampling of the atomistic structures with minimum computational cost, and 3) how to precisely predict the energies of a system with long-range electron transfer interaction (e.g., systems of oxide-on-metal structure with those adsorbates have good electron affinity [101]). 6 Conclusion and perspectives The integration of data science into electrocatalysis has revolutionized the discovery of high-performance catalysts for sustainable energy technologies. Initially, DFT provided low-dimensional frameworks to guide catalyst design. Now, the field has evolved into a high-dimensional paradigm powered by large-scale datasets. ML models decode intricate patterns within these datasets, enabling rapid screening of material compositions, catalytic activity predictions, and synthesis pathway optimization. Meanwhile, MLPs bridge quantum-level accuracy with computational efficiency, accelerating energetic calculations and simulating dynamic catalytic processes. While these advancements mark transformative progress, further opportunities exist to deepen data science’s impact: 1. Advancing DFT for realistic catalytic systems: While DFT-derived descriptors have guided catalyst design, their narrow applicability to specific reactions and inherent scaling relationships limit performance predictions. Future efforts should focus on developing generalized descriptors that transcend reaction-specific constraints and breaking scaling relationships in catalytic reactions. Additionally, electrocatalyst surfaces often undergo reconstruction, adsorbate coverage, or vacancy formation during operation, significantly altering their activity and stability. Integrating chemical surface state analysis—such as potential-dependent surface configurations or solvation effects—into DFT frameworks will refine mechanistic understanding and improve catalyst design for real-world electrochemical environments. 2. High-throughput construction of surface-state databases: Current electrocatalyst datasets largely overlook the dynamic surface coverage change and reconstructions due to the computational cost of modeling adsorbate coverages and interfacial reconstructions [34,102,103]. Accurate modeling of surface states under electrochemical conditions requires accounting for diverse adsorption sites and coverages, significantly increasing computational cost. The combinatorial growth of surfaces and terminations in multicomponent materials further adds to the complexity. The advancement of ML and MLPs enables efficient dataset construction, systematically accelerating the creation of large-scale datasets that include surface coverage information. This approach provides a more comprehensive data science framework for electrocatalysis, facilitating the optimization of catalyst performance under diverse reaction conditions. Open-access repositories with standardized surface-state metadata will further support the development of ML-driven electrocatalyst models. 3. Expanding beyond supervised learning: ML for electrocatalyst design predominantly relies on supervised learning, which requires extensive, high-quality labeled data that is costly and time-consuming to obtain. Expanding the use of semi-supervised and unsupervised learning, which require partial or no labeled data, can reduce labeling demands and improve efficiency. By leveraging unlabeled data or small labeled datasets, these approaches can uncover hidden patterns through methods beyond traditional supervised regression or classification models. This shift provides more flexible design options, accelerating the exploration of new catalyst designs and expanding the potential for discovering novel materials and optimizing catalyst performance. 4. MLPs in electrocatalysis: Although MLPs show promise in materials design, their applications to electrocatalysts remain limited. The complexity of electrocatalytic systems and the need for high-quality datasets across various catalytic environments are major challenges. The further development of MLPs could focus on faster, more accurate simulations of catalytic processes, enabling real-time analysis, improving model transferability, and providing deeper insights into catalyst design, accelerating the discovery of new electrocatalysts for sustainable energy applications. Also, the number of applications of MLP into predicting the realistic surface states under electrochemical conditions is particularly important [104], but the number of related works is still very limited. Besides, integrating physical insights, models (e.g., microkinetic/volcano models), and effects beyond atomistic structures (e.g., the effects of electric field [105] and potential of zero charge [106]) into MLPs may help to simulate electrocatalysis more precisely. 5. Large language models: Recent advancements in large language models (LLMs), such as ChatGPT, leverage deep learning architectures trained on extensive datasets to synthesize scientific knowledge and generate actionable insights for real-world applications. LLMs have been applied to data extraction from literature and crystal structure text representations. However, there are only a few examples of LLM applications in electrocatalysis. Notable examples include accelerating the exploration of electrochemical C−H oxidation reactions [107], developing an enhanced corpus of CO2 reduction electrocatalysts [108], and predicting energy for adsorption configurations [109]. The use of LLMs in electrocatalyst research can facilitate more efficient, data-driven catalyst development by uncovering hidden patterns, predicting catalytic behavior, and optimizing electrocatalysts for diverse applications. Besides, it should be noted that most of the current LLMs for materials science were trained based solely on text information; however, current LLM models are still not able to precisely capture the correct data information due to the complexities of electrocatalysis literature and it’s figure information (some important benchmarking can be found in Ref. [21] and the DigCat platform: www.digcat.org) – this signifies the importance of using standardized and well-labeled data in LLM training together with their corresponding text information in the literature. coredata.dc:description: The integration of data science into electrocatalysis has revolutionized the discovery of high-performance catalysts for sustainable energy applications. To emphasize the role of data science and guide future research in electrocatalyst design, this mini-review traces the evolution from low-dimensional data science—rooted in density functional theory (DFT) descriptors such as d-band center and binding/adsorption energies—to high-dimensional analytics powered by large-scale computational datasets and machine learning (ML). First, DFT-derived parameters establish predictive volcano models for various electrochemical reactions, linking atomic-scale descriptors to macroscopic performance within the framework of low-dimensional data science. Meanwhile, with the development of large-scale datasets, ML deciphers complex structure–property relationships, accelerating the design of promising electrocatalysts. Additionally, machine learning potentials (MLPs) bridge quantum precision and scalability, not only accelerating thermodynamic adsorption energy calculations but also enabling simulations of dynamic catalytic mechanisms more efficiently. Finally, we discuss emerging opportunities to deepen data science’s impact. This mini-review highlights the transformative role of data science in bridging theoretical insights, computational efficiency, and experimental validation, ultimately accelerating the design of next-generation electrocatalysts for a sustainable energy future.
